posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Another dumb question from the Stagmeister...I'm now looking at a predominantly WM build (25 or 28 levels) and (given that you won't let me take EW or EF as bonus feats, you rotters), I find myself with a 'spare' bonus feat - so, taking WoC for a second weapon? Does that allow all the same bonuses (Ki Crit/Inc Multiplier/SWF) on the new weapon to apply immediately, or do they need to be 'earned'?

Thanks in advance

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: You have to take Weapon Focus in that weapon before making it a weapon of choice, but then you get all the benefits on that weapon right away. If you do that, you will need to think about Improved Critical, Epic Weapon Focus, Weapon Spec, and Epic Weapon Spec, all the feats you took for your first weapon of choice. Note that I said you need to think about those feats, not that you must take them.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Thanks Empyre, I'm going for a 'less is more' approach (or a 'fewer options, less chance of buggering it up' approach - it's all semantics), so chucking more feats at the build would render the necessity of taking a second WoC feat redundant! Am quite cross about the whole thing, actually - I had wanted to take Barbarian/WM and ended up with Fighter/WM simply because a Weapon Master can't specialise in that weapon - hence the extra feats, hence the initial question...

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: If you're doing 2 weapons, choose a 1-handed weapon (with a shield) and a 2 handed weapon, like scimitar and heavy flail, for more flexibility. With the heavy flail, don't bother with Improved Crit, Ov Crit and Dev Crit, but do take EWF, WS /EWS (and of course the WF that you must take as a prerequisite). The heavy flail would be taking advantage of the extra AB from WM, crushing those with crit immunity. As always, also carry a ranged weapon even if you're terrible with it, for those rare occasions when you need one.
